title: 5 questions about pizza you didn’t know you had
text:
5 questions about pizza you didn’t know you had

Photo credit: Duke University Archives on Visual hunt / CC BY-NC-SA

Pizza might just be the perfect food. Depending on the toppings, one bite could even include every food group! But where does it come from? Was it always sold in slices? To find the answers to these questions and more, read on!

Where does the pizza come from?

Pizza being made in a pizzeria in Naples, Italy. (Photo credit: marziabertelli on Visualhunt / CC BY-NC-ND)

Human beings have been eating food similar to pizza for a long, long time. Many cultures were known to eat flatbreads topped and flavoured with different ingredients. However, most historians trace the origins of modern day pizza back to the city of Naples, in Italy. Pizza, which means pie in Italian, had long been a popular street food in Naples. However, it wasn’t until the 19th century that it really began to look, and taste, like the pizza we know today.

Is there a royal pizza?

Margherita pizza. (Photo credit: Ozchin on VisualHunt / CC BY-SA)

One of the most famous origin stories says that on June 11th, 1889, the king and queen of Italy were visiting Naples. The local pizzaiolo (pizza maker), Raffaele Esposito, created a new pizza topped with red tomatoes, white mozzarella, and green basil — the colours of the Italian flag — as a tribute to their visit. The queen, Margherita, loved the new dish. Because of this, the new kind of pie became known as Pizza Margherita.

How did pizza come to North America?

Getting a tour of Lombardi's original pizza oven. Lombardi's was the first pizza parlour to open in New York city in 1905. (Photo credit: WWJE on Visualhunt / CC BY)

As Italian immigrants made their way to North America, they brought their local cuisine with them, including pizza. The first known pizzeria popped up in New York in 1905, and more followed in other big cities. However, these first pizza places were thought of as serving an exotic foreign food. This began to change after World War II as many returning veterans had developed a taste for pizza from their time in Naples! Back home, they introduced their families to this "exotic" treat.

Has pizza always been sliced?

Photo credit: JEO Photography on VisualHunt / CC BY-NC-ND

Originally, in Italy, pizza was sold as smaller whole pies. It’s hard to say who first had the genius idea of cutting a pizza into slices and selling it that way. One popular story from turn of the century explains how pizza sellers in New York would walk up and down the street with metal washtubs full of pizzas on their heads, sell the pizza for pennies a slice.

Like unique pizza toppings? Would you try these 10 unique pizzas?

Are there regional pizzas?

Chicago deep dish pizza. (Photo credit: marcoverch on VisualHunt / CC BY)

With its rise in popularity, pizza spread and developed in a lot of different ways. Today, different places are famous for their unique versions of pizza. For example, Chicago pizza is made in a deep dish, with a crust on the bottom. In the middle is usually a pound of shredded cheese and other toppings, and then the whole thing is topped with tomato sauce and baked. Some people say it’s more like a casserole than a pizza!



Hawaiian pizza. (Photo credit: stevendepolo on VisualHunt / CC BY)

Another regional variation is Hawaiian pizza, which has pineapple on it. Except, get this: it’s not Hawaiian at all! It’s Canadian! Hawaiian pizza was invented in Chatham, Ontario, back in 1962!
